title: Stoicism 101
subtitle: How to apply the ancient wisdom of seneca, epictetus and marcus aurelius to your modern life
synopsis: I love Stoicism. In this class we take a quick look at the cast of characters (from founder Zeno to Seneca + Epictetus + Marcus Aurelius) and then dive into the ultimate goal of Stoicism (hint: become bff‚Äôs with your inner daimon so you can experience a state of well-being and flourishing) along with the practices that help us apply this wisdom to our lives. We‚Äôll create energized tranquility and equanimity as we have fun becoming our own ideal sages.

title: The Nicomachean Ethics
author: Aristotle
synopsis: Aristotle's writings have been extraordinarily influential since ancient times. This treatise is named after his son and is a collection of his lecture notes--imagining attending his Lyceum and listening to him teach 2,300 years ago! Of course, it's packed with culture-changing Big Ideas. Some of my favorites we cover include the ultimate end: eudaimonic happiness (vs. "happiness" as most of us think about it!), how to achieve that eudaimonia (hint: "virtuous activity of the soul" aka aret√©), how to win the Olympic Games (hint: you can't just show up; you need to ACT!), the doctrine of the mean (and the vice of deficiency + excess) and the virtue of magnanimity: meet YOUR great soul.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
synopsis: Marcus Aurelius was the Emperor-Philosopher of the Roman Empire and one of the most enlightened leaders ever. Meditations is a collection of journal entries he wrote to himself and in this Note, we'll explore some Big Ideas of his Stoic philosophy‚Äîfrom the importance of never confusing ourselves with visions of a lifetime all at once, to not worrying about what others think of us and living a life of purpose and service.

title: Discourses
author: Epictetus
synopsis: Epictetus is known as one of the world‚Äôs leading Stoic philosophers. (Along with Seneca and Marcus Aurelius, the three make up a very interesting bunch.) Epictetus was a former slave turned philosopher who lived from 55-135 (a little later than Seneca and before Aurelius). This book is a transcription of the informal lectures Epictetus gave to his students. It‚Äôs awesome. Big Ideas we explore: why Hercules needed challenges (and so do you), what figs can teach us about greatness, the good + the bad + the indifferent and how to tell the difference, ‚Äúimpressions‚Äù and the tricks they play, and the fact NOW is the time to live this stuff.

title: On the Shortness of Life
subtitle: Life Is Long If You Know How to Use It
author: Seneca
synopsis: Seneca was an old-school Roman statesman and one of history‚Äôs leading Stoic philosophers. In this book he tells us that life is only short if you don‚Äôt know how to use it and also gives us some tips on how to deal with challenging times and cultivate tranquility. Big Ideas we explore include making T.O.D.A.Y. the day, how to deal with being exiled (never know when it could happen ;), and why flexibility is the virtuous road to tranquility (and how to avoid the detours).

title: The Bhagavad Gita
subtitle: A Classic of Indian Spirituality
author: Krishna & Eknath Easwaran
synopsis: The classic text of Hinduism is *packed* with wisdom. In the Note, we take a super quick look at the context for the book and then jump into some powerful wisdom‚Äîincluding the importance of meditation, the fact that making mistakes is an inherent part of our growth process and the uber-importance of letting go of our attachment to results.

title: The Dhammapada
subtitle: The Sayings of Buddha
author: Eknath Easwaran
synopsis: A core text of Buddhism, The Dhammapada literally means something along the lines of "the path of truth and righteousness" and is packed with wisdom. In this Note, we'll take a quick look at some central tenets of Buddhism (like the Four Noble Truths, nirvana, and the eightfold path) and soak up some Buddha mojo on how to rock our wisest lives.

title: The Way of the Bodhisattva
author: Shantideva
synopsis: The Way of the Bodhisattva is one of the classics of Buddhism that teaches us the key elements of the Bodhisattva‚Äîone who has dedicated his or her life to serving the world and releasing all sentient beings from suffering. In this Note, we‚Äôll check out the importance of cultivating bodhichitta (an ‚Äúawakened mind‚Äù) and how we can do it. (Hint: It‚Äôs all about ‚Äúdiligence in virtuous ways‚Äù! :)

title: Rumi Daylight
subtitle: A Day Book of Spiritual Guidance
author: Rumi
synopsis: Rumi's poetry is stunning. In this Note, we'll explore some inspiring wisdom from the Sufi mystic and have fun applying it to our 21st century lives‚Äîfrom the importance of having patience and seeing challenging times as God's way of strengthening us to working hard and going for it.

title: The Analects of Confucius
author: Confucius
synopsis: Confucius. Talk about old school. I‚Äôve waded through some of the arcane stuff from his classic "Analects" to bring us some highly practical wisdom for our 21st century lives. We'll take a look at a bunch of Big Ideas on the importance of being a passionate (and patient!) student of life while striving to do our best. Good stuff.

title: The Tao Te Ching
author: Lao Tzu
synopsis: The Tao te Ching. It's the core text of Taoism and one of the top old school classics of all time. In this Note, we'll take a look at everything from making use of solitude to the fact that the journey of a thousand miles begins with the first step (heard that before, eh?!). We'll also learn to let go of our attachment to future results and gracefully roll with the ebbs and flows of life.

title: Trying Not to Try
subtitle: Ancient China, Modern Science, and the Power of Spontaneity
author: Edward Slingerland
synopsis: Edward Slingerland is one of the world‚Äôs leading experts on both ancient Chinese thought AND modern cognitive science. This book is a melding of those two realms. It‚Äôs a truly fascinating read. I read it in a day and felt like I was spending the day hanging out with a brilliant thinker‚Äîgetting privileged access to twenty years of deep thinking. If you‚Äôre into ancient wisdom and modern science I think you‚Äôll love the book as much as I did. Big Ideas we explore include defining wu-wei + de (one of the coolest words/concepts ever), what Confucius + Lao Tzu + Mencius + Chuang Tzu have to say about wu-wei, and the spontaneity of mirrors.

title: The Jefferson Bible
subtitle: The Life and Morals of Jesus of Nazareth
author: Thomas Jefferson
synopsis: The Jefferson Bible. Thomas Jefferson created it for himself and never intended it for broad publication. Jefferson *literally* snipped out the passages and parables (from four different translations of the Bible) that he felt best captured the essence of Jesus‚Äôs moral philosophy and conformed with his sense of reason. Big Ideas we cover: Love your enemies (+ everyone else), seek ye first the kingdom of God, take the beam out your eye, use your talents, and build your life on the rock of wisdom.

title: The Daily Stoic
subtitle: 366 Meditations on Wisdom, Perseverance, and the Art of Living
author: Ryan Holiday & Stephen Hanselman
synopsis: This book combines two of my favorite things: Stoicism + Ryan Holiday‚Äôs wisdom. Stoicism was one of the most influential philosophy of the Roman world and has continued to influence many of history‚Äôs greatest minds. As Ryan says: It‚Äôs time to bring it back as a powerful tool ‚Äúin the pursuit of self-mastery, perseverance, and wisdom.‚Äù This is one of the my favorite books ever. Big Ideas we explore: the #1 thing to know about Stoicism, how to create tranquility, a good answer to ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the latest and greatest?!,‚Äù the 2 essential tasks in life and the art of acquiescence (aka amor fati).

title: The Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
synopsis: Epictetus is one of three Stoic philosophers we profile (Marcus Aurelius and Seneca are the other two) and this former slave turned leading philosopher of his era is incredible. He echoes the wisdom of all the great teachers as he reminds us that, if we want to be happy, we've gotta realize the only thing we have control over is our response to a situation. We'll have fun tapping into a lot more of his vast mojo in the Note.

title: The Inner Citadel
subtitle: The Meditations of Marcus Aurelius
author: Pierre Hadot
synopsis: Pierre Hadot was one of the most influential historians of ancient philosophy. In this book, he gives us an incredible look at Marcus Aurelius and his classic Meditations. You can feel Hadot‚Äôs incredible intellectual rigor and equally incredible passion for engaged philosophy. It‚Äôs inspiring. Big Ideas we explore include spiritual exercises, your inner citadel, your daim≈çn, amor fate, turning obstacles upside down and carpe aret√©.

title: How to Think Like a Roman Emperor
subtitle: How to Think Like a Roman Emperor
author: Donald Robertson
synopsis: Donald Robertson is one of the world‚Äôs leading thinkers, writers AND practitioners of Stoic philosophy. He‚Äôs also a therapist who integrates Stoicism into his work with individuals. This is our second Note on one of his great books. The first Note was on The Philosophy of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy in which he connects the philosophical underpinnings of CBT (one of the most empirically-validated, effective modern therapies) to ancient Stoicism. This book is part biography and part philosophy. It‚Äôs all awesome. If you want to know how to think like a Roman emperor, start here. I think you‚Äôll enjoy the book as much as I did.

title: How to Be Free
subtitle: An Ancient Guide to the Stoic Life (Ancient Wisdom for Modern Readers)
author: Epictetus & A. A. Long
synopsis: A.A. Long is professor emeritus of classics and affiliated professor of philosophy at the University of California, Berkeley. He is also one of the world‚Äôs most respected scholars of Stoicism. As per the inside flap, in this beautiful little (hand)book, he provides ‚Äúsplendid new translations and the original Greek on facing pages, a compelling introduction that sets Epictetus in context and describes the importance of Stoic freedom today, and an invaluable glossary of key words and concepts. The result is an unmatched introduction to this powerful method of managing emotions and handling life‚Äôs situations, from the most ordinary to the most demanding.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include freedom vs. slavery, the ultimate target (progress!), wisdom daggers (ready at hand), Rule #1 of Stoicism, how to win at life and using our full powers.

title: How to Be a Stoic
subtitle: Using Ancient Philosophy to Live a Modern Life
author: Massimo Pigliucci
synopsis: Massimo Pigliucci is a Professor of Philosophy at City College of New York. He has three PhDs‚Äîone in genetics, another in evolutionary biology and a third in philosophy. And, most importantly for our purposes, he‚Äôs a practicing Stoic philosopher. In this book, Professor Pigliucci teaches us how to be a Stoic via an imaginary dialogue with Epictetus, one of the leading Stoic teachers of the ancient world. It‚Äôs a wonderfully written, super-smart look at how we can use ‚Äúancient philosophy to live a modern life.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include an introduction to our guide Epictetus, Rule #1 of Stoicism (some things are in our power, others are not), the cardinal virtues (of Stoicism + Science + Optimize), the power of role models (and the Stoic Paradox), and the ultimate how to be a Stoic practice question: How can I use virtue here and now?

title: The Practicing Stoic
subtitle: A Philosophical User's Manual
author: Ward Farnsworth
synopsis: Ward Farnsworth is the Dean of the University of Texas School of Law. As you can imagine, he brings a logical precision to his discussion of Stoicism that is distinct and powerful. Big Ideas we explore include Principle #1 of practical Stoicism (Judgment!), the good life vs. the good mood (virtue for the win!), what others think (<- pro tip: ignore it), preferred indifference (committed but not attached), and using adversity as fuel for our Optimizing (use Hermes' magic wand!).

title: The Obstacle Is the Way
subtitle: The Timeless Art of Turning Trials into Triumph
author: Ryan Holiday
synopsis: Ryan Holiday is brilliant. So is this book. The ancient Stoics taught us how to not only accept challenges but to thrive on them. Ryan brings their wisdom to life with compelling stories of great peeps who have rocked it in the face of adversity. In the Note we'll take a quick look at the three keys to making obstacles work for us: Perception + Action + Will.

title: The Philosophy of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy
subtitle: Stoic Philosophy as Rational and Cognitive Psychotherapy
author: Donald Robertson
synopsis: Got problems with your soul? These days, you‚Äôd see a psychotherapist. But, back in the day, it was the philosopher who‚Äôd help you optimize‚Äîthey were the preferred physician of the soul. This book is about the philosophical roots of modern psychotherapy. Specifically, it outlines the connection between cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and Stoicism. Big Ideas we explore include being a warrior of the mind vs. a librarian of the mind, your highest human purpose, getting on good terms with your inner daimon, practicing the reserve clause and modeling your ideal sage.

title: Musonius Rufus
subtitle: Lectures and Sayings
author: Cynthia Arrieu-King
synopsis: Musonius Rufus was one of the four great Roman Stoics. In fact, he was known as the ‚ÄúRoman Socrates.‚Äù To put him in historical context with the other three great Roman Stoics: He was born in AD 30, about 34 years after Seneca. Epictetus died in 135 but taught the guys who taught the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius (who was born in AD 121) his Stoic philosophy‚Äîwhich is why Aurelius refers to him more than any other teacher in Meditations. Big Ideas we explore include: Theory vs. Practice (which is more important?), practicing philosophy (is where it's at!), vice vs. exile (free yourself from vice!), food (it's the medicine of life), and stoic love advice (competing in kindness).

title: The Stoic Challenge
subtitle: A Philosopher's Guide to Becoming Tougher, Calmer, and More Resilient
author: William B. Irvine
synopsis: William B. Irvine is a professor of philosophy at Wright State University. He‚Äôs also a fantastic (and prolific) writer. We featured another one of Professor Irvine‚Äôs great books on Stoicism called A Guide to the Good Life. I enjoyed that one quite a bit but I REALLY (!) enjoyed this one. Like, jumbo loved it. In fact, I‚Äôm going to put this one right at the top of our growing collection of books on Stoicism‚Äîalong with the must-read classics by Aurelius (Meditations), Seneca (Letters from a Stoic, On the Shortness of Life), and Epictetus (Discourses, Enchiridion) plus the modern classics like Ryan Holiday‚Äôs The Obstacle Is the Way and The Daily Stoic. If you‚Äôre looking for ‚ÄúA Philosopher‚Äôs Guide to Becoming Tougher, Calmer, and More Resilient,‚Äù I think you‚Äôll enjoy it as much as I did. I HIGHLY recommend it.

title: Thoughts of a Philosophical Fighter Pilot
author: James Stockdale
synopsis: Vice Admiral James Stockdale is an American hero. Stockdale spent nearly eight years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam. He spent four of those years in solitary confinement and was repeatedly tortured. He was the commanding officer of hundreds of other U.S. soldiers and received the Medal of Honor for his service beyond the call of duty. This is an incredibly inspiring look at the powerful mind and equally powerful moral commitment of a hero. Big Ideas we explore: Being our brother‚Äôs keeper, chiseling our integrity to achieve delight with life, courage as endurance of the soul and heroes vs. bums.

title: Courage Under Fire
subtitle: Testing Epictetus's Doctrines in a Laboratory of Human Behavior
author: James Stockdale
synopsis: James Stockdale spent 7 1/2 years as the highest ranking prisoner of war during the Vietnam War. 4 years in solitary confinement. 2 in leg irons. This book is about how he endured all of that with the wisdom of Stoic philosopher Epictetus in mind. In the Note, we explore the key tenets of Stoicism, the Stockdale Paradox, playing your role well and mastering your emotions.

title: Ego Is the Enemy
author: Ryan Holiday
synopsis: Meet the enemy: Your ego. Our guide, Ryan Holiday, wrote one of my favorite books of 2015: The Obstacle Is the Way. Ego Is the Enemy is now one of my favorite books of 2016. Big Ideas we explore include: defining ego, becoming more than a flash in the pan, finally answering the question of whether it takes 10,000 or 20,000 hours to attain mastery, the virtue and value of staying true to your own path and making it rather than faking it.

title: Stillness Is the Key
author: Ryan Holiday
synopsis: This is our fourth Note on one of Ryan Holiday‚Äôs books. Ryan is one of my absolute favorite writers. One of the testimonials in the front of the book perfectly captures my sentiment. Screenwriter and director Brian Koppelman (Rounders, Ocean‚Äôs Thirteen and Billions) puts it this way: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have many rules in life, but one I never break is: If Ryan Holiday writes a book, I read it as soon as I can get my hands on it.‚Äù (btw: Cal Newport‚Äôs the first testimonial. Of course, the book‚Äôs packed with Big Ideas and I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorites so let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: Letters from a Stoic
author: Seneca
synopsis: Seneca. He was born around the same time as Jesus and was one of the leading figures in his Roman Empire. He was also one of history's leading Stoic philosophers (along with Marcus Aurelius and Epictetus who we also profile) and has some powerful wisdom to share. In this Note, we'll explore the purpose of philosophy, the importance of focusing our attention and the mojo that comes from facing our fears.

title: A Guide to the Good Life
subtitle: The Ancient Art of Stoic Joy
author: William B. Irvine
synopsis: Stoicism. I love it. Although pretty obscure today, Stoicism was once the primary philosophy of the Western world. (We‚Äôve done Notes on the three leading Stoics: Marcus Aurelius and his Meditations, Seneca and his Letters from a Stoic, and Epictetus and his Enchiridion.) In this, Note, we‚Äôll cover some of the essential ideas of the Stoic philosophical approach along with some Big Ideas on the art of living, the true meaning of virtue, how to visualize and the fact that we‚Äôre living in a dream world.

title: The Stoic Art of Living
subtitle: Inner Resilience and Outer Results
author: Tom Morris
synopsis: This is our fourth Note on one of Tom Morris‚Äôs books. As we discussed in our Notes on True Success, The Art of Achievement, and Superheroes and Philosophy, Tom Morris got a dual Ph.D. from Yale in Philosophy and Religious Studies. Big Ideas we explore include: Inner Confidence (and how to build it; remember: "Disaster is virtue's opportunity."), philosophy and what it's really about, how to deal with stress (pro tip: put it in a cosmic perspective), authentic living (and how to train it), and an emperor's wisdom for the battles of life.

title: Man's Search For Meaning
subtitle: An Introduction to Logotherapy
author: Viktor Frankl
synopsis: Viktor Frankl survived the horrors of the holocaust and describes his Logotherapy in this classic book. In the Note, we'll explore the fact that our attitudes determine our happiness and that *no one* can ever take away the freedom for us to choose our response to any given situation. We'll also look at the importance of having a mission in life and that as we serve something bigger than ourselves, our happiness and success will follow.

title: Plato‚Äôs Lemonade Stand
subtitle: Stirring Change into Something Great
author: Tom Morris

Big Ideas we explore include lemon alchemy (Antifragility for the win!), the Big 3 + 1 (Socrates + Aristotle + Ockham --> Self-knowledge + Ideals + Courage + Simplicity), Plato‚Äôs Ideals (and yours), ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Getting Nervous!‚Äù (--> ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting ready!‚Äù), and The Alchemy of Life (fuel for the second mountain).

title: Superheroes and Philosophy
subtitle: Truth, Justice, and the Socratic Way (Popular Culture and Philosophy)
author: Matt Morris & Tom Morris
synopsis: Tom Morris is one of my favorite modern philosophers. He has a dual Ph.D. from Yale in both Philosophy and Religious Studies. He also taught at Notre Dame for 15 years before becoming one of the most sought-after practical philosophers. We‚Äôve featured two of his other books in which he brings ancient wisdom to our modern lives: True Success and The Art of Achievement. (He‚Äôs also the philosopher behind Philosophy for Dummies and wrote If Aristotle Ran General Motors and If Harry Potter Ran General Electric.) I loved diving into some of the deeper philosophical questions inherent to our modern superhero tales. If that sounds like fun, I‚Äôll think you‚Äôll enjoy it as well. Of course, the book is packed with Big Ideas so, KABAM! Let‚Äôs throw on our spandex tights and capes and jump straight in.

title: Beyond Religion
subtitle: Ethics for a Whole World
author: Dalai Lama
synopsis: I got this book after Ray Dalio strongly recommended it in Principles. It‚Äôs always a joy to read the words of a wise master. The Dalai Lama‚Äôs incredible thoughtfulness, humility, and grounded wisdom is inspiring. Big Ideas we explore include how to rethink secularism and create an ethics for a whole world, moving from knowing to doing, emotions (helpful or not vs. feel good or bad), contentment (material vs. mental), plus some meditation tips.

title: The Miracle of Mindfulness

author: Thich Nhat Hanh

Big Ideas we explore include what qualifies as a miracle (hint: it‚Äôs ALL a miracle), choosing to sit or stand but avoiding the wobble, how to balance on top of a bamboo pole and three questions to ponder.

title: No Mud, No Lotus
subtitle: The Art of Transforming Suffering
author: Thich Nhat Hanh
synopsis: Thich Nhat Hanh is one of the world‚Äôs leading Buddhist monks. He is a true master and it‚Äôs a joy to connect with his powerful wisdom. Big Ideas we explore include: suffering goes with happiness, lotus flowers don‚Äôt grow in marble, feed the good stuff, the first thing to do when suffering strikes (breathe!), billions of funerals/b-days every day, the two arrows, and why the Buddha meditated after becoming the Buddha.

title: Fear
subtitle: Essential Wisdom for Getting Through the Storm
author: Thich Nhat Hanh
synopsis: A Vietnamese Buddhist Zen master, Thich Nhat Hanh is, essentially, a living saint. In this great little book, Nhat Hanh delivers his essential wisdom on how to navigate the storms of life with more grace and poise as we cultivate fearlessness/nonfear. Big Ideas range from breathing in the moment, reflecting on interbeingness (= huge), and enhancing our energy of mindfulness and concentration.

title: Peace Is Every Step
subtitle: The Path of Mindfulness in Everyday Life
author: Thich Nhat Hanh
synopsis: A humble Buddhist monk, Thich Nhat Hanh is one of the most revered spiritual leaders on the planet. This book is a collection of wisdom from his talks and private conversations and is packed with peaceful wisdom. In the Note, we‚Äôll explore Big Ideas ranging from the importance of our breath and what he calls ‚Äúmouth yoga‚Äù (aka smiling :) to how we can practice engaged mindfulness.

title: Buddhism Day by Day
subtitle: Wisdom for Modern Life
author: Daisaku Ikeda
synopsis: Buddhism Day by Day is a collection of thoughts from Daisaku Ikeda, the leader of Nichiren Buddhism and one of the most respected Buddhist philosophers alive whose work has inspired millions around the world. It‚Äôs a very ENGAGED form of Buddhism that I love. Big Ideas we explore include: True enlightenment, making a vow, the real optimism, repaying debts of gratitude, nourishing our soul and how to measure our true worth.

title: The Places that Scare You
subtitle: A Guide to Fearlessness in Difficult Times
author: Pema Ch√∂dr√∂n
synopsis: We've all got places that scare us and in her great book, Pema Chodr√∂n helps us shine a compassionate light on them. We'll explore some Brilliant Ideas including the fact that being mad at someone and holding a grudge is kinda like eating rat poisoning thinking you're going to hurt the rat. Not so much. We'll also look at idiot compassion and the practice of rejoicing in others' good fortune and other wonderfulness.

title: The Diamond Cutter
subtitle: The Buddha on Strategies for Managing Your Business and Your Life
author: Geshe Michael Roach
synopsis: The wise Michael Roach was an undercover Buddhist monk who used a classic sutra from Buddhism (called The Diamond Cutter) to build a diamond business. In his book, he describes how he successfully applied this classic wisdom to his modern business and in the Note, we'll take a look at some of my favorite Big Ideas‚Äîincluding the fact that the world is "empty" of meaning and we always have the ability to see its hidden potential.

title: Big Mind Big Heart
subtitle: Finding Your Way
author: Genpo Roshi
synopsis: Zen Master Genpo Roshi spent decades figuring out how to best help people develop enlightened awareness and came up with his revolutionary process called "Big Mind." In this Note, we'll take a peek at some Big Ideas from the Zen Master including how the root of suffering (dukkha) is getting stuck in one perspective and how that's about as effective as having a Maserati stuck in first gear. We'll also explore the place beyond idiot compassion as we become integrated human beings giving ourselves joyfully to the world.

title: Everyday Zen
subtitle: Love and Work
author: Charlotte Joko Beck
synopsis: Charlotte Joko Beck was the founder and former head teacher at the Zen Center in San Diego. (Very Zen, eh? lol) The book is a collection of edited talks Joko gave at her Zen center. It was published in 1989 when she was 82. (She passed away at 94 in 2011.) Fun fact: Joko started practicing Zen at 48. She went on to become an influential figure in the American Zen movement, founding her own approach called Ordinary Mind. So‚Ä¶ If you feel a little ‚Äúbehind‚Äù in any aspect of your life, take heart! :) The book is packed with Big Ideas and I‚Äôm excited to share a few of my favorites with some practical wisdom we can apply to our lives TODAY.

title: The Buddha in Your Mirror
subtitle: Practical Buddhism and the Search for Self
author: Woody Hochswender & Greg Martin & Ted Morino
synopsis: Looking for the Buddha? Cruise on over to your mirror and you'll find him (or her). YOU are the Buddha and this book shows us how to realize that fact and live from that awareness. Big Ideas range from rockin' your swan legs and cleaning your face to become who you are truly are.

title: Passage Meditation
subtitle: Bringing the Deep Wisdom of the Heart into Daily Life
author: Eknath Easwaran
synopsis: This book could have been called ‚ÄúThe Eight-Point Program for Daily Living‚Äù as Eknath Easwaran walks us through not just his approach to ‚Äúpassage meditation‚Äù but also the other key tenets of spiritual living. Big Ideas we explore include deciding whether you *really* want to get over your problems, how to tame your mind (and why it‚Äôs like an elephant‚Äôs unruly trunk!), making your mind one-pointed, swimming upstream and doing the work (vs. just attending lectures).

title: Knowledge of Higher Worlds and its Attainment
author: Rudolf Steiner
synopsis: I got this book on the recommendation of Phil Stutz (author of The Tools). I recently hired Phil as my coach and he *loves* Rudolf Steiner. I love Phil and I love following Joseph Campbell‚Äôs advice to study the books the teachers you admire studied so here we are. Rudolf Steiner was a remarkable man. Born in 1861, he was a philosopher, architect, and social reformer. Big Ideas we explore: the fundamental attitude of your soul, the importance of cultivating courage (and how to do it), spiritual perfection (it‚Äôs your ultimate goal), unfailing mastery (is the key), and using all your powers to serve profoundly.

title: Sapiens
subtitle: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Yuval Noah Harari

title: Positive Psychology 101
subtitle: How to tap into the science of optimizing + actualizing
synopsis: I LOVE the science of flourishing. In this class, we have fun exploring my absolute favorite Big Ideas from my absolute favorite psychologists. Life-changing stuff. The psychologists: Maslow + Frankl + Csikszentmihalyi + Seligman + Dweck + Baumeister + Ben-Shahr + Oettingen + Segar + McGonigal. The Ideas: Actualizer + Choice + Flow + Virtues + Mindsets + Willpower + Optimalist + WOOP + Why + Stress.

title: Motivation and Personality
author: Abraham Maslow
synopsis: Abraham Maslow tells us, "What one can be, one must be!" (OMG I love that.) He was a 20th century humanistic psychologist who came up with the hierarchy of needs and studied the most exceptional people of his era. In this Note, we'll explore some of the Big Ideas on how we can be all that we're destined to be and look at some of the characteristics of those self-actualizing human beings who're rockin' it.

title: Man's Search For Meaning
subtitle: An Introduction to Logotherapy
author: Viktor Frankl
synopsis: Viktor Frankl survived the horrors of the holocaust and describes his Logotherapy in this classic book. In the Note, we'll explore the fact that our attitudes determine our happiness and that *no one* can ever take away the freedom for us to choose our response to any given situation. We'll also look at the importance of having a mission in life and that as we serve something bigger than ourselves, our happiness and success will follow.

title: Flourish
subtitle: A Visionary New Understanding of Happiness and Well-being
author: Martin Seligman
synopsis: Martin Seligman is one of the founding fathers of the Positive Psychology movement and this is the third Note we‚Äôve done on one of his books. (Check out the Notes on his other classics: Learned Optimism and Authentic Happiness for more science of happiness goodness.) In this Note, we‚Äôll explore his shift from Authentic Happiness Theory to Well-Being Theory as we wrap our brains around PERMA, his model of well-being that consists of Positive emotions + Engagement + Relationships + Meaning + Achievement. Good times.

title: Rethinking Positive Thinking
subtitle: Inside the New Science of Motivation
author: Gabriele Oettingen
synopsis: Gabriel Oettingen is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers in ‚ÄúThe New Science of Motivation.‚Äù The basic idea of the book is captured in a clever image on the cover: Rose colored glasses with one lens cracked. Oettingen walks us thru the compelling research that demonstrates the power of seeing both the positive AND the challenges. When we contrast our wishes with the obstacles to their attainment we, almost magically, catalyze an extraordinarily higher level of performance.

title: Grit
subtitle: The Power of Passion and Perseverance
author: Angela Duckworth
synopsis: Angela Duckworth is the world‚Äôs leading authority on the science of grit. In fact, she pioneered the field and, as Daniel Gilbert says on the cover: ‚ÄúPsychologists have spent decades searching for the secret of success, but Duckworth is the one who found it.‚Äù In this Note, we explore the two facets of grit (hint: passion + perseverance, why they‚Äôre important and how to cultivate them.

title: The Joy of Movement
subtitle: How exercise helps us find happiness, hope, connection, and courage
author: Kelly McGonigal
synopsis: I‚Äôm a big fan of Kelly McGonigal and her ability to help us apply scientific wisdom to our lives. We‚Äôve covered two of her earlier books: The Willpower Instinct and The Upside of Stress. So... When I got this book, knew I‚Äôd enjoy it. But, I didn‚Äôt anticipate JUST how much I‚Äôd love it. We have some great Notes on Movement (Spark, Spartan Up and No Sweat among my favorites), but Kelly‚Äôs book will be our new go-to for the science of WHY exercise/movement is so essential to our well-being. It‚Äôs PHENOMENAL. Reading about the SCIENCE behind stories of transformation (and how, as per the sub-title of her book: ‚ÄúExercise Helps Us Find Happiness, Hope, Connection, and Courage‚Äù) also made me that much more clear on the power of what we‚Äôre doing with all of our work and the importance of focusing so much on Energy (especially with our Mastery and Coach programs). Big Ideas we explore include: Hope Molecules (and how to create them), persistence highs (and how to create them), collective effervescence (and why it's so awesome), how we endure (hint: TOGETHER!), and OMMS!!! (Obstacles (literally!) Make Me Stronger!).

title: What Doesn't Kill Us
subtitle: The New Psychology of Posttraumatic Growth
author: Stephen Joseph Ph.D.
synopsis: Stephen Joseph is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers on the science of posttraumatic growth. He is also a professor and therapist. He started his career studying posttraumatic stress. In the process, he saw that many people experienced significant growth as a result of the stress they endured--at which point, he started developing his ideas on posttraumatic growth. Fast-forward a few decades and here we are. the title is a play on Nietzsche‚Äôs famous dictum: ‚ÄúWhat doesn‚Äôt kill me makes me stronger.‚Äù While the sub-title perfectly captures the focus of the book: ‚ÄúThe New Psychology of Posttraumatic Growth.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include: Eudaimonic Treadmills (note: there aren't any!), posttraumatic growth (and how to use stress as the engine for growth), the shattered vase (taking the pieces and making an antifragile mosaic), harvesting hope (the 1 + 2 + 3s for trauma survivors).

title: Peak
subtitle: Secrets from the New Science of Expertise
author: Anders Ericsson & Robert Pool
synopsis: Anders Ericsson is the world‚Äôs leading scientist studying expert performance‚Äîlooking at how, precisely, the people who are the best in the world at what they do became the best. In this Note, we take a quick look at The Gift that we all have that‚Äôs the key to our potential greatness, HOW to go about tapping into the benefits of that gift via a certain type of practice (forget naive practice and go for purposeful + deliberate!), the fact that there is no such thing as a ‚Äú10,000 Hour Rule,‚Äù and why we should be called Homo Exercens rather than Homo Sapiens. :)

title: Presence
subtitle: Bringing Your Boldest Self to Your Biggest Challenges
author: Amy Cuddy
synopsis: Amy Cuddy is awesome. Her TED talk is the 2nd most popular ever. This book is just as good. Learn the science of cultivating your personal power to bring your boldest self to your biggest challenges. Big Ideas we explore: self-affirmation theory, priming + nudges, the magic of expanding your body to increase your power, iHunch (how‚Äôs yours?), and the boldest you.

title: Happier
subtitle: Learn the Secrets to Daily Joy and Lasting Fulfillment
author: Tal Ben-Shahar
synopsis: Tal Ben-Shahar is one of my favorite teachers. He taught one of the most popular classes in Harvard's history and this book captures the essence of his class on Positive Psychology‚Äîsharing the best of what we scientifically know about how to create happier, more fulfilled lives. We'll explore how important it is to have goals AND be in the moment (and the perils of *just* being in the moment) along with mucho m√°s goodness.

title: Gratitude Works!
subtitle: A 21-Day Program for Creating Emotional Prosperity
author: Robert A. Emmons
synopsis: I‚Äôm grateful for Robert Emmons. He‚Äôs dedicated the last three decades of his life to understanding the science of how to boost our well-being. In the process, he‚Äôs conducted ground-breaking research on the power of gratitude. In fact, he‚Äôs basically THE researcher we have to thank for understanding *just* how powerful gratitude journaling is. (He's also served as editor-in-chief of The Journal of Positive Psychology.) I consider myself a reasonably grateful guy but this book has opened my eyes to JUST how powerful gratitude is. And, to just how important it is to DELIBERATELY PRACTICE it. Big Ideas we explore include: How to give yourself a 25% (!!!) boost in happiness, the top gratitude practices, the #1 obstacle to gratitude (and its remedy), and using challenges for grateful fuel!

title: Future Visions
subtitle: The Unpublished Papers of Abraham Maslow
author: Dr. Edward Hoffman
synopsis: As you know if you‚Äôve been following along, I love Abraham Maslow and feel a deep kinship to him and his work. We have featured two of the books he published during his lifetime: Toward a Psychology of Being and Motivation and Personality. Although this book has only ONE review on Amazon and I could only buy a used copy of it, I knew I‚Äôd love it. And, although I had already been deeply influenced by Maslow and his thinking, there was something about reading his unpublished essays and journal thoughts that made me feel that much more connected to this great man. Big Ideas we explore include Maslow‚Äôs thoughts on the ‚Äúeupsychian ideal‚Äù (aka: the ‚Äúeudaemonic ideal‚Äù!), the psychology of happiness (eudaimonology!!), Stoic philosophy (Maslow was a fan), vicious cultural influences (Maslow was NOT a fan!), and the Jonah Complex (ANSWER YOUR HEROIC CALL, already!!).

title: Happy Together
subtitle: Using the Science of Positive Psychology to Build Love That Lasts
author: Suzann Pileggi Pawelski, MAPP & James O. Pawelski Ph.D.
synopsis: Suzie and James Pawelski are two of the world's leading positive psychologists. James cofounded the Master of Applied Positive Psychology program at the University of Pennsylvania with Martin Seligman while Suzie is a graduate of the program and a leading freelance writer and consultant. Together they've written an incredible book on "Using the Science of Positive Psychology to Build Love That Lasts." I‚Äôve been waiting for a very long time for the book that would make me say: ‚ÄúREAD THIS BOOK if you want to figure out how to integrate Ancient Wisdom + Modern Science + Practical Tools to Optimize your relationship.‚Äù And, well, THIS book is it. I HIGHLY recommend it. In fact, it's not only my #1 Love book recommendation, it's also cracked the Top 10 all-time greatest list. Big Ideas we explore include The Relationship Gym (hit it!), Aristotelian Lovers (the REAL Soul Mates), SNAP (James geniuses x2), Know Thy... (self and thy partner!), and Love Is an Action Verb (let's commit to flourishing together TODAY!).

title: The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work
subtitle: A Practical Guide from the Country's Foremost Relationship Expert
author: John M. Gottman & Nan Silver
synopsis: Want to make your relationship work? Then you‚Äôd be wise to turn toward the world‚Äôs leading researcher on the science of what makes love work: John Gottman. This book has sold over 1 million copies and it‚Äôs easy to see why. Big Ideas we explore: How Gottman can predict divorce with 91% accuracy (in < 15 minutes), a quick look at the 7 principles, the power of cherishing your partner, turning toward (and not being a tech rat), how to solve the solvable problems and starting ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù with the ‚ÄúI.‚Äù

title: The How of Happiness
subtitle: A Scientific Approach to Getting the Life You Want
author: Sonja Lyubomirsky
synopsis: People often ask me what *one* book I would recommend they read. I never had an answer I felt good about until I read this book. It's amazing. The PhilosophersNotes workbook. How can you beat 1,000 Big Ideas from 100 great books packed into 600 pages? ;)

title: The Upside of Stress
subtitle: Why Stress Is Good for You, and How to Get Good at It
author: Kelly McGonigal
synopsis: If you‚Äôve ever had stress in your life (hah!) and wondered how to deal with it more optimally, I think you‚Äôll love this. McGonigal tells us that how we THINK about stress plays a huge role in its affect on us and walks us thru the science behind it. Rather than try to get rid of stress (good luck with that!), we‚Äôre much better off shifting our mindsets to embrace and use the stress wisely!

title: The Happiness Hypothesis
subtitle: Finding Modern Truth in Ancient Wisdom
author: Jonathan Haidt
synopsis: Wonder where happiness comes from? So does Jonathan Haidt, one of the world‚Äôs leading positive psychologists and Professor at the University of Virginia. In this phenomenal book, Haidt looks at ancient wisdom and modern wisdom as he tests some happiness hypotheses and comes up with his ultimate hypothesis. In this Note, we‚Äôll check out the dynamic between you and your elephant, the magic pill that is meditation, and the mojo of virtue.

title: Flow
subtitle: The Psychology of Optimal Experience
author: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
synopsis: Flow. It's all about the science of optimal human experience. In this Note, we'll explore what the flow state is (hint: get fully engaged in an activity that matches your skills with your challenge) and we‚Äôll look at some other Big Ideas on controlling the contents of our consciousness to get out of anxiety and boredom as we create more flow experiences in our lives. (Plus, you'll even learn how to pronounce "Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi.")

title: The Myths of Happiness
subtitle: What Should Make You Happy, but Doesn't, What Shouldn't Make You Happy, but Does
author: Sonja Lyubomirsky
synopsis: Sonja Lyubomirsky is one of the world‚Äôs leading positive psychology researchers. I always love connecting ancient wisdom and fun self-help with SOLID research so this book was a great treat. Big Ideas: hedonic adaptation, #1 way to boost optimism (kinda surprising), the ultradian dip, affluenza virus, frequency > intensity and how to set goals.

title: The Psychology of Hope
subtitle: You Can Get There from Here
author: Charles R. Snyder
synopsis: Rick Snyder was the founder of research into the science of hope. And, he was one of the pioneers of the positive psychology movement. In fact, he literally wrote the textbook on ‚ÄúPositive Psychology.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include the three components of hope (goals + willpower + way power), the portrait of a high-hope person, how to create the right goals, remembering you WILL face obstacles, the power of multiple pathways and being a time traveler making a difference.

title: Making Hope Happen
subtitle: Create the Future You Want for Yourself and Others
author: Shane J. Lopez, PhD
synopsis: Did you know there's a science of hope? Yep. And Shane Lopez is the world's leading researchig studying the science of hope. This book is an inspiring look at the nuts and bolts of cultivating hope. Big Ideas we explore include differentiating hope from fantastizing and dwelling, the three keys to hope (goals + agency + pathways) , futurecasting, sirens, when/where plans and why hope is so important for leadership.

title: Constructive Living
subtitle: Outgrow Shyness, Depression, Fear, Stress, Grief, Chronic Pain. Achieve the Goal of Constructive Living - To Do Everything Well
author: David K. Reynolds
synopsis: Dan Millman (author of Way of the Peaceful Warrior and other great books) introduced me to this book as he's been deeply influenced by David Reynolds' integration of Zen Buddhism and Western Psychotherapy. In this Note, we'll explore some Big Ideas on how to live with greater self-mastery by more effectively relating to our emotions and consistently asking ourselves: "Now what needs to be done?!"

title: Creativity
subtitle: The Psychology of Discovery and Invention
author: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
synopsis: Creativity with a capital C‚Äîthe type of Creativity that changes the world. How can we go about cultivating it in our lives? That‚Äôs what this book is all about. Our guide is the legendary psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. Big Ideas we explore include defining true Creativity, focusing our attention and being willing to be kinda weird, the one personality trait all Creators have in common (hint: complexity!), creating rhythms and the nine elements of flow and how to tap into it!

title: The As If Principle
subtitle: The Radically New Approach to Changing Your Life
author: Richard Wiseman
synopsis: William James once said: ‚ÄúIf you want a quality, act as if you already have it.‚Äù In this book, Richard Wiseman, Britain‚Äôs official professor in ‚Äúthe Public Understanding of Psychology‚Äù walks us through the astonishing array of research that proves what he calls the ‚ÄúAs If Principle.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include an exploration of the fact that feelings follow behavior, how to make yourself happy, the paradox of rewards, and how to create a new you.

title: Thanks!
subtitle: How Practicing Gratitude Can Make You Happier
author: Robert A. Emmons
synopsis: Robert Emmons is one of the world's leading experts on the science of gratitude and this book is packed with the whys and hows of getting our gratitude on. In this Note, we'll explore Big Ideas on how we can boost our happiness by 25% by simply keeping a daily gratitude journal, how to get our relationships flourishing, the importance of seeing challenges as opportunities for growth and more goodness.

title: Authentic Happiness
subtitle: Using the New Positive Psychology to Realize Your Potential for Lasting Fulfillment
author: Martin Seligman
synopsis: Martin Seligman is essentially the father of the Positive Psychology movement and in this Note we explore how important it is for us to use our Signature Strengths consistently throughout our day-to-day lives. We've got tips on how to discover our Strengths and how to move from a job to a career to a calling as we live a life of meaning and purpose. Good times.

title: Learned Optimism
subtitle: How to Change Your Mind and Your Life
author: Martin Seligman
synopsis: Did you know you can learn optimism? Yep. And, unfortunately, we can also learn helplessness. Whether we're helpless or optimistic is one of the biggest predictors of whether we're emotionally happy/healthy or depressed/unhealthy so this is BIG. In this Note, we'll explore some great Ideas on how to get our optimism on by creating more empowering explanations of what's happening in our lives.

title: The Courage Quotient

author: Robert Biswas-Diener
synopsis: Robert Biswas-Diener is known as the ‚ÄúIndiana Jones of positive psychology.‚Äù As per his bio, ‚Äúhis research has taken him to such far-flung places as Greenland, India, Kenya and Israel.‚Äù And, important note: ‚ÄúHe is afraid of quicksand and snakes.‚Äù :) Robert is also the son of one of the leading positive psychology researchers: Ed Diener. We covered a book they wrote together called Happiness. This is basically the ONLY book on science of courage. It's fantastic. Big Ideas we explore include defining the numerator and denominator of our Courage Quotient (hint: Increase your "willingness to act" and "ability to control fear"), courage's two flavors (general + personal), courage blindness (and how to heal it), the power of playing our roles well (choose a courageous one!), being willing to fail and playing to win.

title: The Philosophy of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy
subtitle: Stoic Philosophy as Rational and Cognitive Psychotherapy
author: Donald Robertson
synopsis: Got problems with your soul? These days, you‚Äôd see a psychotherapist. But, back in the day, it was the philosopher who‚Äôd help you optimize‚Äîthey were the preferred physician of the soul. This book is about the philosophical roots of modern psychotherapy. Specifically, it outlines the connection between cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and Stoicism. Big Ideas we explore include being a warrior of the mind vs. a librarian of the mind, your highest human purpose, getting on good terms with your inner daimon, practicing the reserve clause and modeling your ideal sage.

title: The Power of Ideals
subtitle: The Real Story of Moral Choice
author: William Damon & Anne Colby
synopsis: William Damon and Anne Colby are two of the world‚Äôs leading researchers in the field of moral psychology. They‚Äôre both Professors at Stanford and have been married for 30+ years. Damon and Colby argue that we all have the power to cultivate our more noble, moral possibilities. Big Ideas we explore include a quick look at our moral exemplars, moral agency, and the three virtues we want to cultivate: Truth + Humility + Faith.

title: The Marshmallow Test

Their ability to delay gratification (or not!) led to shocking correlations related to how they fared on all kinds of measures years + decades later‚Äîfrom SAT performance to body mass index. Here‚Äôs the guide on how to develop your self-control.

title: The Power of Character Strengths

This book is ‚ÄúAn Official Guide from the VIA Institute on Character‚Äù that helps us ‚ÄúAppreciate and Ignite Your Positive Personality.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include a quick look at the VIA origin story, the 24 character strengths (you know the Top 5?), finding balance (underuse vs. overuse vs. optimal use!) and the Top 2: Hope + Zest!

title: Character Strengths Matter
subtitle: How to Live a Full Life (Positive Psychology News)
author: Shannon M. Polly, MAPP, ACC & Kathryn Britton, MAPP

In our Note, we take a quick look at all 24 virtues and explore some practical ways to apply them to our lives TODAY.

title: The Pursuit of Perfect

title: The Power of Agency

title: Counterclockwise
subtitle: Mindful Health and the Power of Possibility

title: Happiness
author: Ed Diener & Robert Biswas-Diener

(Love that. :) In their great book, Happiness, they give us a comprehensive look at what we KNOW creates happiness. In this Note, we‚Äôll have some fun figuring out how we can become psychological billionaires as we master the happiness equation, become loving and caring angels, and take AIM at happiness.

title: Emotional Intelligence
subtitle: The Groundbreaking Book That Redefines What it Means to be Smart
author: Daniel Goleman

In this Note, we'll explore some (really) Big Ideas on how to scientifically get our emotional intelligence on‚Äîfrom the power of delaying gratification to how worrying can act as self-fulfilling prophecies.

title: Why We Do What We Do

author: Edward L. Deci
synopsis: Edward L. Deci is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers on human motivation and this book is *packed* with scientific wisdom‚Äîexploring what we know about the power of intrinsic motivation (vs. extrinsic motivation), the importance of autonomy (vs. being controlled) and the need for authenticity (vs. alienation). title: Self-theories

title: Mindset
subtitle: The New Psychology of Success

She tells us that our ‚Äúmindset‚Äù‚Äîhow we see the world‚Äîdetermines a *huge* part of our overall happiness and well-being and achievement. In this Note, we‚Äôll explore the difference between a ‚Äúfixed mindset‚Äù and a ‚Äúgrowth mindset‚Äù and some Big Ideas on why we want to learn how to live from a growth mindset. And, of course, how to do it!

title: Willpower
subtitle: Rediscovering the Greatest Human Strength
author: Roy Baumeister & John Tierney

In fact, in their *great* book, Willpower, Roy Baumeister (one of the world‚Äôs leading scientific researchers on self-control) and John Tierney (science writer for the New York Times) tell us that ‚ÄúImproving willpower is the surest way to a better life.‚Äù In this Note, we‚Äôll learn how to eat our way to willpower (seriously), how to exercise our self-control muscles, why ‚Äúprecommitment‚Äù is so important and how to win the willpower game with bright lines and a great offense. :)

title: The Willpower Instinct
subtitle: How Self-Control Works, Why It Matters, and What You Can Do to Get More of It
author: Kelly McGonigal

The Willpower Instinct by award-winning Stanford Professor Kelly McGonigal, Ph.D., is a GREAT book based on ‚ÄúThe Science of Willpower‚Äù class Kelly teaches through Stanford University‚Äôs Continuing Studies program. It‚Äôs *packed* with super practical Big Ideas on the newest scientific insights about self-control to explain how we can ‚Äúbreak old habits and create healthy habits, conquer procrastination, find our focus, and manage stress.‚Äù In this Note, we‚Äôll check out the #1 way to build willpower (it‚Äôs not what you‚Äôd guess), how to give ourselves willpower boosts throughout the day and other stress-relief strategies that rock.

title: The Paradox of Choice - Why More Is Less
author: Barry Schwartz

In the Note, we'll explore the difference between being a ‚ÄúMaximizer‚Äù vs. a ‚ÄúSatisficer‚Äù and why we want to shift from always needing the ‚Äúabsolute best‚Äù to being happy with ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù as we develop our gratitude and quit comparing ourselves to other peeps. Powerful.

title: A Guide to Rational Living
author: Albert Ellis & Robert Harper

title: Toward a Psychology of Being
author: Abraham Maslow

title: The Upward Spiral

author: Alex Korb, PhD

Big Ideas we explore include the power of exercising your brain (which is the #1 tip, btw), setting goals (and making decisions), developing positive habits (via repetition, repetition, repetition), biofeedback (and how to take advantage of it), and the power of others (rely on it!).

title: I Can If I Want To

author: Arnold Lazarus

title: Getting Grit

title: Pursuing the Good Life

title: Positive Psychology and the Body
subtitle: The Somatopsychic Side to Flourishing
author: Dr. Kate Hefferon, PhD

It's actually a *textbook* not a normal book. It provides an overview of research on a range of subjects including: ‚ÄúPositive Psychophysiology,‚Äù ‚ÄúPositive Neuroscience,‚Äù ‚ÄúPositive Sexuality‚Äù and ‚ÄúPositive Nutrition.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include a quick look at Martin Seligman's PERMA approach to eudaimonic (vis-a-vis hedonic) happiness, your nervous system (flip the switch!), longevity and positive emotion (some astonishing stats), diet and wellbeing/depression (sugar begone!), and physical activity (science says: it does a body good!).

title: The Happiness Trap
subtitle: How to Stop Struggling and Start Living
author: Dr. Russ Harris
synopsis: ACT. That‚Äôs where it‚Äôs at. This is our second Note on Russ Harris and his great introduction to Acceptance and Commitment Therapy. (Check out the Notes on The Confidence Gap as well.) In this book, Russ walks us through how we get caught in the happiness trap and, more importantly, how to free ourselves. We‚Äôll take a quick look at the myths of happiness, the six principles of ACT, how to deal with emotional quicksand, how NOT to visualize (and what to do instead), and writing down your values (<‚Äî science says that‚Äôs wise).

title: The Telomere Effect
subtitle: A Revolutionary Approach to Living Younger, Healthier, Longer

title: Stoicism 101
subtitle: How to apply the ancient wisdom of seneca, epictetus and marcus aurelius to your modern life
synopsis: I love Stoicism. In this class we take a quick look at the cast of characters (from founder Zeno to Seneca + Epictetus + Marcus Aurelius) and then dive into the ultimate goal of Stoicism (hint: become bff‚Äôs with your inner daimon so you can experience a state of well-being and flourishing) along with the practices that help us apply this wisdom to our lives. We‚Äôll create energized tranquility and equanimity as we have fun becoming our own ideal sages.

title: The Daily Stoic
subtitle: 366 Meditations on Wisdom, Perseverance, and the Art of Living
author: Ryan Holiday & Stephen Hanselman
synopsis: This book combines two of my favorite things: Stoicism + Ryan Holiday‚Äôs wisdom. Stoicism was one of the most influential philosophy of the Roman world and has continued to influence many of history‚Äôs greatest minds. As Ryan says: It‚Äôs time to bring it back as a powerful tool ‚Äúin the pursuit of self-mastery, perseverance, and wisdom.‚Äù This is one of the my favorite books ever. Big Ideas we explore: the #1 thing to know about Stoicism, how to create tranquility, a good answer to ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the latest and greatest?!,‚Äù the 2 essential tasks in life and the art of acquiescence (aka amor fati).

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
synopsis: Marcus Aurelius was the Emperor-Philosopher of the Roman Empire and one of the most enlightened leaders ever. Meditations is a collection of journal entries he wrote to himself and in this Note, we'll explore some Big Ideas of his Stoic philosophy‚Äîfrom the importance of never confusing ourselves with visions of a lifetime all at once, to not worrying about what others think of us and living a life of purpose and service.

title: Courage Is Calling
subtitle: Fortune Favors the Brave (The Stoic Virtues Series)
author: Ryan Holiday
synopsis: This is our fifth note on one of Ryan Holiday‚Äôs books. As I told my wife Alexandra after reading the first part of this book ‚ÄúRyan is truly an INCREDIBLE writer.‚Äù As in, an ASTONISHINGLY compelling writer. He has truly mastered his craft‚Äîwhich is why he‚Äôs one of the world‚Äôs bestselling living philosophers whose books have sold more than four million copies. The book has three parts: Part I on Fear; Part II on Courage; and Part III on The Heroic. It‚Äôs packed with Big Ideas. Let‚Äôs explore a few my favorites now as we strive to show up with more Wisdom, Self-Mastery, COURAGE, and Love‚Äînot someday but TODAY.

title: The Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
synopsis: Epictetus is one of three Stoic philosophers we profile (Marcus Aurelius and Seneca are the other two) and this former slave turned leading philosopher of his era is incredible. He echoes the wisdom of all the great teachers as he reminds us that, if we want to be happy, we've gotta realize the only thing we have control over is our response to a situation. We'll have fun tapping into a lot more of his vast mojo in the Note.

title: Discourses
author: Epictetus
synopsis: Epictetus is known as one of the world‚Äôs leading Stoic philosophers. (Along with Seneca and Marcus Aurelius, the three make up a very interesting bunch.) Epictetus was a former slave turned philosopher who lived from 55-135 (a little later than Seneca and before Aurelius). This book is a transcription of the informal lectures Epictetus gave to his students. It‚Äôs awesome. Big Ideas we explore: why Hercules needed challenges (and so do you), what figs can teach us about greatness, the good + the bad + the indifferent and how to tell the difference, ‚Äúimpressions‚Äù and the tricks they play, and the fact NOW is the time to live this stuff.

title: Letters from a Stoic
author: Seneca
synopsis: Seneca. He was born around the same time as Jesus and was one of the leading figures in his Roman Empire. He was also one of history's leading Stoic philosophers (along with Marcus Aurelius and Epictetus who we also profile) and has some powerful wisdom to share. In this Note, we'll explore the purpose of philosophy, the importance of focusing our attention and the mojo that comes from facing our fears.

title: On the Shortness of Life
subtitle: Life Is Long If You Know How to Use It
author: Seneca
synopsis: Seneca was an old-school Roman statesman and one of history‚Äôs leading Stoic philosophers. In this book he tells us that life is only short if you don‚Äôt know how to use it and also gives us some tips on how to deal with challenging times and cultivate tranquility. Big Ideas we explore include making T.O.D.A.Y. the day, how to deal with being exiled (never know when it could happen ;), and why flexibility is the virtuous road to tranquility (and how to avoid the detours).

title: Musonius Rufus
subtitle: Lectures and Sayings
author: Cynthia Arrieu-King
synopsis: Musonius Rufus was one of the four great Roman Stoics. In fact, he was known as the ‚ÄúRoman Socrates.‚Äù To put him in historical context with the other three great Roman Stoics: He was born in AD 30, about 34 years after Seneca. He taught Epictetus (who was born in AD 55). Epictetus died in 135 but taught the guys who taught the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius (who was born in AD 121) his Stoic philosophy‚Äîwhich is why Aurelius refers to him more than any other teacher in Meditations. Big Ideas we explore include: Theory vs. Practice (which is more important?), practicing philosophy (is where it's at!), vice vs. exile (free yourself from vice!), food (it's the medicine of life), and stoic love advice (competing in kindness).

title: How to Think Like a Roman Emperor
subtitle: How to Think Like a Roman Emperor
author: Donald Robertson

This is our second Note on one of his great books. The first Note was on The Philosophy of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy in which he connects the philosophical underpinnings of CBT (one of the most empirically-validated, effective modern therapies) to ancient Stoicism. This book is part biography and part philosophy. It‚Äôs all awesome. If you want to know how to think like a Roman emperor, start here. I think you‚Äôll enjoy the book as much as I did.

author: Ryan Holiday
synopsis: Ryan Holiday is brilliant. So is this book. The ancient Stoics taught us how to not only accept challenges but to thrive on them. Ryan brings their wisdom to life with compelling stories of great peeps who have rocked it in the face of adversity. In the Note we'll take a quick look at the three keys to making obstacles work for us: Perception + Action + Will.

author: Pierre Hadot

Big Ideas we explore include spiritual exercises, your inner citadel, your daim≈çn, amor fate, turning obstacles upside down and carpe aret√©.

synopsis: A.A. Long is professor emeritus of classics and affiliated professor of philosophy at the University of California, Berkeley. As per the inside flap, in this beautiful little (hand)book, he provides ‚Äúsplendid new translations and the original Greek on facing pages, a compelling introduction that sets Epictetus in context and describes the importance of Stoic freedom today, and an invaluable glossary of key words and concepts. The result is an unmatched introduction to this powerful method of managing emotions and handling life‚Äôs situations, from the most ordinary to the most demanding.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include freedom vs. slavery, the ultimate target (progress!), wisdom daggers (ready at hand), Rule #1 of Stoicism, how to win at life and using our full powers.

author: Massimo Pigliucci

It‚Äôs a wonderfully written, super-smart look at how we can use ‚Äúancient philosophy to live a modern life.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include an introduction to our guide Epictetus, Rule #1 of Stoicism (some things are in our power, others are not), the cardinal virtues (of Stoicism + Science + Optimize), the power of role models (and the Stoic Paradox), and the ultimate how to be a Stoic practice question: How can I use virtue here and now?

author: Donald Robertson

title: The Stoic Challenge

author: William B. Irvine

In his book, he describes how he successfully applied this classic wisdom to his modern business and in the Note, we'll take a look at some of my favorite Big Ideas‚Äîincluding the fact that the world is "empty" of meaning and we always have the ability to see its hidden potential.

title: Purpose 101
subtitle: How to discover your purpose and fulfill your destiny
synopsis: Abraham Maslow tells us that what one can be, one must be. Actualizing our potential is like oxygen for the soul. Helping you discover your purpose and fulfill your destiny is what this class is all about.

title: Purpose 102
subtitle: Bonus Video: 25 Journaling Questions
synopsis: 25 journaling questions on how to discover your purpose and fulfill your destiny.

title: The Hero with a Thousand Faces
subtitle: The Collected Works of Joseph Campbell
author: Joseph Campbell
synopsis: Joseph Campbell was an American author and teacher best known for his work in the field of comparative mythology. If you‚Äôve ever heard of the ‚ÄúHero‚Äôs Journey,‚Äù you have him and his lifelong commitment to studying mythology to thank. This book (written in 1949) is the one that captures the essence of his thoughts on the ‚Äúmonomyth‚Äù that shows up across all cultures. One universal hero. A thousand faces. Big Ideas we explore include: a quick look at the hero‚Äôs journey, moving past the veil of the unknown (aka romancing your discomfort zone) while creating micro hero journeys (all day every day), your ultimate boon (don‚Äôt make King Midas‚Äôs mistake), the mistake that the makers of legend made (growth mindset, guys!!), and a portrait of the modern hero (look in the mirror!).

title: The Power of Myth
author: Joseph Campbell
synopsis: Ah, The Power of Myth. We'll learn how Campbell came up with the admonition to "follow your bliss!" (hint: it's from the Upanishads), the importance of loving our fate, how we're helped by hidden hands when we really commit to our paths and so much more.

title: Pathways to Bliss
subtitle: Mythology and Personal Transformation
author: Joseph Campbell
synopsis: This is one of the three books by Campbell we cover and in this Note, we'll learn why following our bliss is so important (hint: our bliss is the transcendent wisdom within us bubbling up!) and how we can more courageously follow it in our lives (hint: say "Yes!" to life more often!). We'll also look at how we can make the simple things in our life part of our heroic journey and how going for it isn't an ego trip.

title: A Joseph Campbell Companion
subtitle: Reflections on the Art of Living
author: Joseph Campbell
synopsis: Joseph Campbell occupies the Grandfather slot in my spiritual family tree and this book is an incredible collection of some of his most inspiring wisdom. In the Note, we'll explore a range of Big Ideas from what it means to (and how to!) follow our bliss as we rock our hero's journey to learning that we've gotta be willing to break some eggs if we want to make omelets (aka, we've gotta be willing to make mistakes as we grow!).

title: Noble Purpose
subtitle: The Joy of Living a Meaningful Life
author: William Damon
synopsis: William Damon is one of the world‚Äôs leading scientists studying human development and the psychology of morality. In this book, he gives us a guide to discovering and creating our noble purpose. Big Ideas we explore include making a distinction between noble and heroic, the ultimate purpose formula, 9 tips on how to cultivate your noble purpose, the one phrase your advisor should whisper in your ears when you‚Äôve achieved ultimate success, and how to create true, sustainable happiness.

title: The Path to Purpose
subtitle: How Young People Find Their Calling in Life
author: William Damon
synopsis: This book is a scientific look at Purpose by one of the world‚Äôs leading developmental psychologists‚Äîa powerful look at how to cultivate purpose in our children (and, for that matter, ourselves) and why it‚Äôs so important. Big Ideas we explore include a definition of what it means to be purposeful (and a look at the alternatives), the #1 thing that gets in the way of discovering and creating purpose, 9 key things parents can do to help their kids with purpose, why entrepreneurial spirit is so important and a four-word mantra to reduce timidity and build courage and confidence.

title: A Round of Golf with My Father
subtitle: The New Psychology of Exploring Your Past to Make Peace with Your Present
author: William Damon
synopsis: This is our fourth note on one of William Damon's books. Professor Damon is one of the world‚Äôs leading scholars on human development across the lifespan. He‚Äôs also an incredibly good human being. In this book, William Damon helps us create a ‚Äúcoherent narrative‚Äù for our lives by, as per the sub-title, ‚ÄúExploring Your Past to Make Peace with Your Present.‚Äù It‚Äôs FANTASTIC. We'll explore the three primary aspects of a 'life review' and a ton of other Big Ideas. Let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: The Power of Ideals
subtitle: The Real Story of Moral Choice
author: William Damon & Anne Colby
synopsis: William Damon and Anne Colby are two of the world‚Äôs leading researchers in the field of moral psychology. They‚Äôre both Professors at Stanford and have been married for 30+ years. This is a thoughtful and thought-provoking book that challenges the ‚Äúnew science of morality‚Äù‚Äôs view that morality is essentially biologically and socially determined. Damon and Colby argue that we all have the power to cultivate our more noble, moral possibilities. Big Ideas we explore include a quick look at our moral exemplars, moral agency, and the three virtues we want to cultivate: Truth + Humility + Faith.

title: The Road to Character
synopsis: In today‚Äôs world, the road to character has a much less defined map than the road to external success. Big Ideas we explore include r√©sum√© virtues vs. eulogy virtues, answering the summons, conquering yourself, living for holiness and becoming strongest at your weakest point.

title: The Second Mountain
subtitle: The Quest for a Moral Life
synopsis: David Brooks is one of the nations‚Äô leading writers and commentators. He is an op-ed columnist for the New York Times and appears regularly on PBS NewsHour and Meet the Press. title: The Great Work of Your Life
subtitle: A Guide for the Journey to Your True Calling
author: Stephen Cope

subtitle: A Spirituality for the Two Halves of Life
author: Richard Rohr, OFM

Big Ideas we explore include our main Job in life (remembering that we're light bulbs and staying screwed in!), life's two major tasks, the fact that the way UP is DOWN (hence, the title of the book: Falling Upward), the hero and the heroine and their journeys, the paradox of the ego ("You ironically need a very strong ego structure to let go of your ego"), and how to become a Serene Disciple (let God drive).

title: Self-Reliance
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

(vs. what will they think?), Hobgoblins (begone), your voyage (of a thousand zigs and zags), and the Royal You (act like that now!).

author: Dr. Edward Hoffman

Big Ideas we explore include Maslow‚Äôs thoughts on the ‚Äúeupsychian ideal‚Äù (aka: the ‚Äúeudaemonic ideal‚Äù!), the psychology of happiness (eudaimonology!!), Stoic philosophy (Maslow was a fan), vicious cultural influences (Maslow was NOT a fan!), and the Jonah Complex (ANSWER YOUR HEROIC CALL, already!!).

title: Life's Great Question
subtitle: Discover How You Contribute To The World
author: Tom Rath

subtitle: Finding Meaning and Direction in a Changing World
author: Dan Millman

It‚Äôs a *remarkably* lucid, concise exposition on the primary tenets of existentialism‚Äîeven more remarkable given the fact that Sartre gave this lecture without notes. Big Ideas we explore: Anguish + its antidote, passion vs. choice, quietism vs. commitment, the stern optimism of existentialism and moral choices as a work of art.

Big Ideas we explore include figuring out what you *really* want in life, becoming the best-version-of-yourself, answering the ultimate question, mastering energy management and learning to take the decade view of your life.

title: Self-Help
author: Samuel Smiles
synopsis: Written in 1859, this is one of the classics of self-development. synopsis: The Art of Possibility. But‚Ä¶ (And this is a big but!), I also don‚Äôt think we should underestimate just how much we play the role of addicted users caught up in the mix of a $7 TRILLION attention economics (/mind-hacking!) industry. ‚Äã‚Äã ‚Äã‚ÄãThe solution: Become Optimizites‚Äîuse technology wisely to become the BEST you rather than mindlessly let your 1 million-year-old prefrontal cortex get hacked all day every day. ‚Äã‚Äã ‚Äã‚ÄãIn the class, we walk through the costs of addiction, then talk about how to conquer it so we can sculpt our ideal lives.

title: Focus

author: Daniel Goleman
synopsis: Daniel Goleman is a former New York Times science writer and author of the uber-bestselling book Emotional Intelligence. In Focus, we look at the underlying neuroscience of attention. Which is why Goleman calls it ‚Äúthe hidden driver of excellence.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include rumination vs. reflection, the three foci of willpower, smart practice and hitting the mental gym.

title: Hyperfocus
subtitle: How to Be More Productive in a World of Distraction
author: Chris Bailey
synopsis: Hyperfocus. Just looking at the cover of this book makes me smile. I got it after Cal Newport connected me with Chris Bailey. Although the book is called ‚ÄúHyperfocus,‚Äù it‚Äôs ultimately about learning how to control our attention‚Äîturning it on AND off at will as we master the process of intentionally entering what Chris calls ‚ÄúHyperfocus‚Äù (think: getting things done/being present mode) AND what he calls ‚ÄúScatterfocus‚Äù (deliberately allowing our minds to wander to enter creative mode). As per the inside flap, it‚Äôs ‚Äúa practical guide to managing your attention‚Äîthe most powerful resource you have to become more creative, get stuff done, and live a meaningful life.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include defining Hyperfocus, establishing how to get into it (including the #1 rule!), the power of specific implementation intentions (vs. "vague" intentions) and how to expand our productivity potential.

Big Ideas we explore include sheep vs. strategists, figuring out your ikigai (= why you get up in the morning), the fascinating endurance of rats with hope, the first two steps in greatness and moving from vision to decision.

Big Ideas we explore include: how to be fully engaged, the #1 goal of meditation, how to get in total control of your life, goal poison, premeditated procedures, and the powerful question: ‚ÄúAnd then what?‚Äù

title: Make Time

title: The Practicing Mind

author: Thomas M. Sterner
synopsis: The Practicing Mind. It‚Äôs the key to true inner peace and contentment. In a world that conditions us to obsess about goals and outcomes, it‚Äôs easy to miss the importance of the process. (Bonus: We also create a frictionless path to our goals as well!)

title: Digital Minimalism

author: Cal Newport

author: Jim Afremow

Big Ideas we explore include seeing setbacks as challenges rather than threats, outperforming our contracts, practicing ‚Äôtill you can‚Äôt get it wrong, and the 3 P‚Äôs of peak performance.

title: The Passion Paradox
subtitle: A Guide to Going All In, Finding Success, and Discovering the Benefits of an Unbalanced Life
author: Brad Stulberg & Steve Magness
synopsis: Brad Stulberg writes, coaches, and speaks on health and human performance. author: Richard Machowicz

In this book, Mack teaches us how we can unleash the warrior within ourselves to, as the sub- title suggests, ‚ÄúDevelop the Focus, Discipline, Confidence, and Courage You Need to Achieve Unlimited Goals.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include World War 0, ‚ÄúNot Dead Can‚Äôt Quit,‚Äù the #1 question (hint: Do you have the guts?), and 110% vs. 80%.

title: #754 How to Make a Pearl
subtitle: To Go with our Diamonds
synopsis: One of our very first +1s was on a brilliant line from Steven Kotler. At the end of our interview about his great book The Rise of Superman,

title: Meditation 101

author: Matthieu Ricard

subtitle: The Sub-Two-Hour Marathon Is Within Reach‚ÄïHere's How It Will Go Down, and What It Can Teach All Runners about Training and Racing

title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
author: Yuval Noah Harari
synopsis: This is Yuval Noah Harari's third book (and our third Note). His first two focused on the past (Sapiens) and the future (Homo Deus). In this one, we "zoom in on the here and now" as we take a look at 21 of the most important things to be thinking about in the 21st century. Like all of his books, this is a thoughtful and thought-provoking look at some globally Big Ideas. Although obviously outside the scope of our normal Optimizing, I think it's important stuff. In the Note we explore dealing with "Disillusionment" (the title of chapter #1) by switching from "panic to bewilderment"), the future of health care and driving (and jobs!), making sure we match our investment in developing AI with an equivalent investment in developing "human consciousness," what we should be teaching our kids (basically, how to Optimize!!), and Yuval's #1 practice: meditation.

title: Black Box Thinking

synopsis: Failure. Some of us lean into it and learn as much as we can from it, and some of us prefer to avoid thinking about it and/or pretend it never happened. As you may guess, one approach leads to dramatically better performance over the long run. (Hint: Seeing failure as feedback + learning opportunities is a very wise idea.) Big Ideas we explore include a quick look at the aviation vs. health care industries, the importance of quantity of work if you want quality, marginal gains, cognitive dissonance and pre-mortems.

(That‚Äôs a lot.) This book captures what he‚Äôs learned about optimizing our brains, why it‚Äôs important and how to do it. Big Ideas we explore include #ANTspray, wisdom from Fat Freddie the penguin, how hungry your brain is (did you know it‚Äôs 2% body weight but uses 20-30% of calories consumed?), and a bunch of other goodness.

author: Yuval Noah Harari

After finishing my Note on his first bestselling book Sapiens I immediately picked up this one. While Sapiens features a ‚ÄúA Brief History of Humankind,‚Äù Homo Deus gives us ‚ÄúA Brief History of Tomorrow.‚Äù Wonder what the future might look like and how artificial intelligence and biotechnology will fundamentally change the world and our species? Well, this is the book for you. It‚Äôs incredibly well-written and thoughtful and thought provoking. I HIGHLY recommend it. Big Ideas we explore include how Harari developed such an extraordinary mind (hint: 10,000+ hours of meditation and no smartphone), why we should study history (hint: to reimagine a better future), the 21st century's Big 3: Immortality + Happiness + Divinity (which results in an upgrade from Homo sapiens to Homo deus!), and algorithms--"arguably the single most important concept of the 21st century.

It‚Äôs a wonderfully written book by Dava Sobel, who combines her background in both astronomy and psychology to give us a behind-the-scenes look at the science and history of time, longitude, and seafaring all wrapped up in one epic heroic quest. If you‚Äôre looking for a fun, quick-reading, mind-expanding escape from the normal self-development literature, I think you‚Äôll enjoy this hero-tale as much as I did. Big Ideas we explore include: clocks and watches (and SUNDIALS!), time (as measured in heartbeats), longitude (vs. latitude), strengths (and weaknesses), encouraging a hero (how will you do so Today?!), Rome wasn‚Äôt built in a day (neither was anything awesome), elegant solutions (and the scientific establishment).

Big Ideas we explore: The 10,000 Hour Rule, no naturals + no grinders, The Beatles (and their 1,200!! shows before they hit it big), Bill Gates sneaking out of bed in high school and the three keys to meaning.

title: Awareness

author: Anthony de Mello
synopsis: Anthony de Mello was a Jesuit priest who integrated Eastern and Western ideas into his teachings and in this Note, we'll explore some of his Biggest Ideas on how to live from a place of deep connection and awareness. title: Gay and Katie Hendricks
author: Gay Hendricks

author: J. K. Rowling

Big Ideas we explore include: the importance of friends (Dumbledore and scientists agree!), liquid luck (remember the U Curve‚Äîtoo much of a good thing *isn‚Äôt* a good thing), cleverer than most? expect correspondingly huger mistakes, the placebo effect and Ron‚Äôs goalkeeping, and walking into the arena with your head held high.

title: Play
subtitle: How It Shapes the Brain, Opens the Imagination, and Invigorates the Soul
author: Stuart Brown
synopsis: Play! Stuart Brown, one of the world's leading play researchers, tells us that it's more important than you may think. subtitle: The Secret to Recognizing and Coping with Narcissists

Big Ideas we explore: the Myth of Narcissus, the Spectrum of Narcissism, healthy narcissism (no, that isn‚Äôt an oxymoron), how to bring it forth in our lives, and the passionate life (passion + compassion = magic!).

Big Ideas we explore include the primary difference between Freud and Adler (hint: etiology vs. teleology), the importance of "separating tasks" (aka: stay out of other people's business and don't let them in yours), the ticket to freedom (hint: the courage to be disliked), the center of the world (<- is not you), and Adler's guiding star (happiness defined as contribution!).
